The post Vegan Blackberry & Vanilla Chia Pudding appeared first on Vegan Food & Living.
item.content:encoded:
This vegan chia pudding is luxuriously layered with the flavours of fresh blackberries and sweet, creamy vanilla pudding. Easy to prep the night before, it’s a wholesome treat that feels like dessert for breakfast.

This is the kind of breakfast that looks fancy but takes no effort at all. The pudding itself is rich and creamy thanks to oat milk and chia seeds, gently spiced with cinnamon and nutmeg for warmth.

Juicy blackberries are simmered into a quick compote with maple syrup and vanilla, then layered up with the pudding for a breakfast pot that’s as pretty as it is satisfying. Best of all, it thickens overnight in the fridge, so it’s ready to grab and go the next morning.

Serve it in jars or ramekins for an easy weekday breakfast, brunch treat, or even a light dessert. Add fresh berries on top for a burst of freshness, or swirl in some vegan yoghurt for extra creaminess.

Jump to:

  • How to make this vegan blackberry & vanilla pudding
  • Ingredients in vegan chia pudding
  • Recipe FAQs

What makes this recipe great

  • Easy overnight breakfast recipe, ideal for busy mornings
  • Vegan blackberry & vanilla chia pudding feels indulgent, but is made with wholesome ingredients
  • A delicious plant-based alternative to fruit yoghurt or bircher muesli
  • Nut-free, soy-free, and suitable for gluten-free vegan diets.
  • Can be enjoyed for breakfast, brunch or dessert
  • Naturally sweetened pudding, made with maple syrup and fruit
  • No cooking skills required, perfect for kitchen novices

How to make vegan blackberry & vanilla chia pudding

Start by making a quick blackberry compote. Place the blackberries, maple syrup, water, vanilla and nutmeg in a small saucepan. Bring to a gentle simmer, then use the back of a fork to lightly crush the berries – you want them to release their juices but still keep some bite.

Once the mixture is gently bubbling, take it off the heat and stir in the chia seeds. Set aside to cool completely; this allows the chia to thicken the compote.

Meanwhile, make the chia pudding base by whisking oat milk with chia seeds, vanilla, nutmeg, cinnamon and maple syrup. It’s important to mix thoroughly to avoid clumps. Let it sit for at least 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it thickens into a pudding-like consistency.

To assemble, layer the chia pudding with the cooled compote in jars or containers, adding fresh blackberries between layers if using. Pop the jars in the fridge to chill – they’ll be ready to enjoy the next morning or even later the same day.

Want to change up the flavours? Try using crushed pistachios or pumpkin seeds to top your pudding. You can also make a chocolate chia pudding layer by adding a tablespoon of cocoa powder or a squeeze of fruit-based chocolate syrup to the mix.

Ingredients in this vegan chia pudding

Chia seeds: The star ingredient. Chia seeds absorb liquid and create a jelly-like consistency, which thickens both the compote and the pudding.

Oat milk: Gives the pudding a creamy, smooth base. Other plant milks such as almond, soy or coconut can be used, but oat keeps it nut-free.

Maple syrup: A natural sweetener that adds depth and caramel notes to both the compote and pudding. You can swap for agave syrup if preferred.

Vanilla extract: Used in both the compote and pudding for a soft, sweet aroma that ties the layers together.

Nutmeg & cinnamon: These warming spices bring subtle depth and enhance the sweetness of the dish.

Blackberries: These give the compote its vibrant colour and fruity tang. Frozen blackberries work just as well as fresh ones and are often more budget-friendly. Fresh blackberries also make an attractive topping.

Vegan Blackberry & Vanilla Chia Pudding FAQs

Is chia pudding healthy?

This easy vegan breakfast contains nutritious chia seeds, offering protein, fibre, healthy fats, calcium, and omega-3 fatty acids. The pudding also offers antioxidant properties from its spices and fresh blackberries, which also boost your fibre intake and add to your 5-a-day.

Can the sugar content be reduced?

For a lower-sugar option, feel free to reduce the maple syrup or swap it for mashed ripe banana in the pudding base.

How should chia pudding be stored?

This vegan chia pudding stores well in the fridge for up to 3 days – perfect for prepping in batches.

Vegan Blackberry & Vanilla Chia Pudding

This vegan chia pudding is luxuriously layered with the flavours of fresh blackberries and sweet, creamy vanilla pudding. Easy to prep the night before, it’s a wholesome treat that feels like dessert for breakfast.
Course Breakfast, Dessert, Snack
Cuisine Latin American
Keyword dairy free, dairy free dessert, healthy, healthy vegan, plant based breakfast, vegan breakfast
Prep Time 10 minutes minutes
Cook Time 10 minutes minutes
Minimum Chilling Time 2 hours hours
Total Time 2 hours hours 20 minutes minutes
Servings 2
Calories 309kcal

Ingredients

For the blackberry compote:

  • 125 g blackberries defrosted if frozen
  • 1 Tbsp maple syrup
  • 60 ml water
  • ½ tsp vanilla extract
  • ¼ tsp nutmeg
  • 1 Tbsp chia seeds

For the chia pudding:

  • 240 ml oat milk use gluten-free, if required
  • 50 g chia seeds
  • 1 tsp vanilla extract
  • ¼ tsp nutmeg
  • ¼ tsp cinnamon
  • 1 Tbsp maple syrup
  • Fresh blackberries optional

Instructions

  • Make the compote by adding all the ingredients, except the chia seeds, to a small pan and bringing them to a gentle simmer. Lightly crush the berries with the back of a fork so that they release their juices but still retain some texture.
  • Remove from the heat and stir in the chia seeds. Set aside to cool completely.
  • Whisk together all the ingredients for the chia pudding in a large bowl. Then set aside to thicken to a pudding consistency.
  • Assemble the puddings by alternating layers of pudding, compote and fresh blackberries in a mason jar or other portable container. Chill until ready to serve.

Notes

For a lower-sugar option, feel free to reduce the maple syrup or swap it for mashed ripe banana in the pudding base.
This vegan chia pudding stores well in the fridge for up to 3 days – perfect for prepping in batches.

item.content:encoded:
Crunchy on the outside, tender on the inside, these vegan chicken wings made with chickpeas are a vegan twist on classic fried comfort food. Quick to make and incredibly moreish, they’re the ultimate finger food for snacking or sharing and make a great vegan alternative to chicken wings.

These vegan chicken wings are crispy, golden and drenched in sweet chilli sauce. They’re the ultimate finger food for snacking or sharing and make a great vegan alternative to chicken wings.

The seitan-like dough, made from blitzed chickpeas and vital wheat gluten, mimics a meaty texture, while a dredge in cornflour gives each piece a satisfying crispiness when shallow-fried. Once golden, they’re tossed in warm, sweet chilli sauce for that irresistible glossy finish.

These vegan chicken wings are ideal as a starter or party snack, especially when paired with dips like vegan mayo, sriracha or smoky barbecue sauce. You can also turn them into a full meal by serving with fries, coleslaw or a crunchy salad.

What makes this vegan chicken wings recipe great:

  • A delicious vegan alternative to chicken wings
  • Perfect for parties, casual dinners, or game night snacks
  • These vegan chickpea wings are a great source of plant protein
  • Sweet chilli sauce adds a bold, sticky glaze
  • Quick to make with no long marinating or oven time needed
  • Uses everyday pantry ingredients
  • Great hot, but still tasty at room temperature

How to make vegan sweet chilli chicken wings:

Start by blending the chickpeas, vital wheat gluten, spices, nutritional yeast and stock in a food processor until the mix comes together into a dough. You want the texture to be smooth and pliable, not crumbly. Turn the dough out onto your worktop and shape it by hand into 12 small ‘wings’, roughly 1cm thick. They don’t need to be perfect; rustic shapes give a homemade charm and crisp up beautifully when fried.

Next, heat oil in a large frying pan over medium heat. Dredge each wing in cornflour just before frying—this helps to create a light, crispy crust. Shallow-fry the wings in batches, cooking each side for 3-4 minutes until golden brown and puffed. Don’t overcrowd the pan, and adjust the heat if they brown too quickly. Once cooked, drain them on kitchen paper.

Warm the sweet chilli sauce in a separate pan and gently toss the fried wings in the sauce to coat. Serve straight away with your favourite dips, or turn them into a meal with chips and slaw.

Ingredients in vegan sweet chilli chicken wings:

Chickpeas: The base of the dough, providing protein, moisture and binding power. Use canned, drained chickpeas for convenience.

Vital wheat gluten: A high-protein flour that is used to make vegan seitan recipes. It gives the wings a firm, chewy texture, essential for mimicking meatiness.

Garlic powder, celery salt, onion salt, sage: These seasonings add savoury depth and a subtle herbiness that echoes classic wing seasoning.

Nutritional yeast: Adds umami and a hint of cheesiness.

Bouillon stock: Infuses the dough with flavour; use a good-quality vegetable stock powder.

Cornflour: Creates a light, crispy coating when the wings are shallow-fried.

Sweet chilli sauce: A ready-made sauce that provides sweet heat and a glossy finish.

Oil: For shallow frying. Use a neutral oil with a high smoke point, like sunflower or rapeseed.

Recipe tips:

Try not to make the wings too thick, as they will expand slightly during cooking. Around 1cm thick is ideal.

If you’re not a fan of frying, you could air fry the wings in batches or bake them in a hot oven (around 200°C fan) until crisp, though they may not be quite as golden.

Vegan Chicken Wings with Sweet Chilli Sauce

These vegan chicken wings are crispy, golden and drenched in sweet chilli sauce. They’re the ultimate finger food for snacking or sharing.
Course Appetizer, Lunch, Snack
Cuisine American
Keyword meat free, savoury vegan, seitan, vegan chicken, vegan meat, vegan snack
Prep Time 20 minutes minutes
Cook Time 15 minutes minutes
Total Time 35 minutes minutes
Servings 12 'wings'
Calories 141kcal

Ingredients

  • 400 g tin chickpeas drained
  • 60 g vital wheat gluten flour
  • 1 tsp garlic powder
  • 1 tsp celery salt
  • 1 tsp onion salt
  • 1 scant tsp sage
  • 2 tsp nutritional yeast
  • 60 ml bouillon powder stock made as per packet instructions
  • 60 g cornflour for dredging
  • Sweet chilli sauce
  • Oil for frying

Instructions

  • Place all the ingredients, apart from the cornflour and sweet chilli sauce, into a food processor and blitz until well combined.
  • Tip out the mixture onto a worktop and bring together to form a dough. Then press small pieces of the dough into wing-like shapes, about 1cm in thickness.
  • Heat the oil in a frying pan to a medium heat, suitable for shallow frying.
  • Dredge each wing in cornflour before placing them in the oil to shallow fry. Cook each wing for 3-4 minutes before turning and cooking for further 3-4 minutes on the other side.
  • When the wings are cooked, drain on kitchen paper. Heat the chilli sauce in another pan and carefully coat the wings in it.
  • Serve immediately, with your favourite dips.

Notes

Try not to make the wings too thick, as they will expand slightly during cooking. Around 1cm thick is ideal.
If you’re not a fan of frying, you could air fry the wings in batches or bake them in a hot oven (around 200°C fan) until crisp, though they may not be quite as golden.

item.content:encoded:
Black pudding may be the most un-vegan food you can think of, but this plant-based version is a delicious addition to breakfast or brunch. Give it a try with this throwback recipe.

Vegan black pudding might sound like an oxymoron, but this clever recipe brings all the deep, earthy flavours of the original, without the blood and guts. Packed with mushrooms, beans and grains, it’s hearty, smoky, and surprisingly simple to make.

The mixture of black beans, chestnut mushrooms, oats and barley gives it a wonderfully dense and satisfying texture, while a careful blend of spices adds warmth and complexity. A touch of activated charcoal powder adds that familiar inky blackness.

Once cooked and sliced, it fries up beautifully to a crisp-edged, savoury treat. Try it as part of a vegan fry-up, served alongside sautéed potatoes and juicy tomatoes, or crumble it into a grain bowl for added punch. It’s perfect for brunch, but don’t be surprised if you find yourself reaching for it at any time of day.

What makes this recipe great:

  • A delicious vegan alternative to traditional black pudding
  • Perfect for weekend brunches or full English breakfasts
  • Packed with plant-based protein from beans, grains and mushrooms
  • This vegan black pudding is free from animal products and cruelty
  • Can be made ahead and stored for quick frying later

How to make vegan black pudding:

Start by cooking your pearl barley in a mix of water, miso paste and bouillon powder until tender. It should absorb most of the liquid while retaining a bit of bite.

Meanwhile, fry mushrooms, garlic and onion in a little oil with a pinch of salt. This step removes moisture and concentrates their umami-rich flavour.

Once softened, transfer the mushroom mix to a food processor and add all the remaining ingredients: black beans, herbs, spices, oats, rice flour, and optional charcoal powder. Pulse until combined, but keep some texture to avoid it turning into a purée.

Scrape the mix onto a sheet of foil and roll it tightly into a sausage shape. Twist the ends to seal, then bake it for an hour in a low oven.

Let it cool completely so it firms up enough to slice neatly. When ready to eat, cut thick slices and fry until golden and heated through.

Ingredients in vegan black pudding:

Pearl barley: Adds chew and bulk to the pudding, giving it a traditional, grainy texture.

Brown miso paste: Provides depth and saltiness. Can be swapped for red miso if preferred.

Garlic and red onion: Build savoury flavour as the aromatic base.

Black beans: The main source of protein and body, with a dark colour that suits the dish.

Chestnut mushrooms: Earthy and umami-rich, they mimic the depth of flavour in traditional black pudding.

Dried thyme, grated nutmeg, allspice, onion salt, sea salt: Create the signature spice blend typical of black pudding.

Rice flour: Helps bind the mixture without making it heavy.

Oats: Add texture and help absorb moisture, similar to traditional versions.

Bouillon powder: Boosts flavour in the barley base; can be replaced with a good-quality stock cube.

Activated charcoal powder: This optional ingredient gives the pudding its classic black colour and may offer added health benefits. If you have extra to use up, why not try our high-protein activated charcoal smoothie recipe for a deliciously dark drink?

Recipe tips:

If you can’t find activated charcoal powder, the recipe still works beautifully without it; it just won’t be quite as dark.

The baked sausage can be kept in the fridge for up to 3 days before baking. Alternatively, freeze the vegan black pudding for longer storage. Defrost overnight in the fridge before you fry it, and ensure it’s thoroughly heated before eating.

Plan ahead to make time for the cooling step. You’ll be much more likely to get firm, sliceable pieces that hold their shape when fried.

Vegan Black Pudding

Black pudding may be the most un-vegan food you can think of, but this plant-based version is a delicious addition to breakfast or brunch. Give it a try with this throwback recipe.
Course Breakfast
Cuisine British
Keyword mushrooms, plant based breakfast, savoury vegan, vegan, vegan breakfast, vegan meat, vegan sausages
Prep Time 25 minutes minutes
Cook Time 1 hour hour 50 minutes minutes
Cooling Time 45 minutes minutes
Total Time 3 hours hours
Servings 8
Calories 126kcal

Ingredients

  • 65 g pearl barley well rinsed
  • 2 tsp brown miso paste
  • 1 Tbsp olive oil
  • 2 cloves garlic peeled and chopped
  • 400 g black beans drained and rinsed
  • 1 tsp dried thyme
  • 1 tsp nutmeg grated
  • 1 tsp sea salt
  • 2 Tbsp rice flour
  • 240 ml water
  • 1 tsp bouillon powder
  • 100 g chesnut mushrooms roughly chopped
  • 1 small red onion peeled and finely chopped
  • 35 g oats
  • 1 tsp onion salt
  • 1 tsp all spice
  • 2 Tbsp activated charcoal powder optional

Instructions

  • Place the barley in a saucepan with the water and add the miso and bouillon. Bring to a simmer and cook for around 45 minutes, or until tender – but not mushy. A lot of the water should have been absorbed, with a small amount remaining. Don’t drain this away.
  • Heat the oil in a frying pan over medium heat and add the mushrooms, garlic, and onions with a pinch of salt. Fry for 5 minutes or until all the liquid has evaporated.
  • Once the mushroom mixture is cooked, scrape it into a food processor. Add all the remaining ingredients and pulse until everything is combined, but it retains some texture.
  • Preheat the oven to 165°C / 325°F / Gas mark 3. Scrape the mixture onto a large sheet of foil and carefully roll it up to make a large sausage shape. Twist the ends to seal before placing it in the oven to bake for 1 hour.
  • Once cooked, remove the package from the oven and set aside to cool. The sausage will firm up as it cools, making it much easier to slice.
  • Fry the sliced black pudding in a splash of oil until piping hot and serve.

Notes

If you can’t find activated charcoal powder, the recipe still works beautifully without it; it just won’t be quite as dark.
The baked sausage can be kept in the fridge for up to 3 days before baking. Alternatively, freeze the vegan black pudding for longer storage. Defrost overnight in the fridge before you fry it, and ensure it's thoroughly heated before eating.
